Can we run the audit on the main branch afterwards? I'll defer to you.

I'd suggest we run these tests once to (have the system) ascertain that indeed this doesn't impact the other platforms. As all else passed I just triggered those runs. We then have a clean decision base to approve/merge. I personally would make the actual merge decision dependent on whether @xvzcf's comment

is addressed in this PR or via creation of a new issue.

issue.title: Cannot run tests?
issue.body:
MacOS 10.15.7, Xcode-12.4 (probably not relevant here, but...).

Initially, I could not run tests because the make-script could not load dynamic library. *Problem with the upstream, unresolved.*

Changing the build to producing static library, the tests can run - but some are skipped with this message:
```
test_tlsextms needs the dynamic engine feature enabled
```

What's this "dynamic engine feature"? How do I enable it - just by removing `no-shared` from the `./Configuration ...` command?

And why the README tells to build this fork with `no-shared`? Is this restriction still valid?

comment.body: Reopening to address the suggestions above.

issue.title: Combine tasks from some CI workflows to speed up builds
issue.body: Could have a single build that does shared, noshared, openssl, noopenssl, clang, gcc, rather than separate builds.  Would reduce overall CI usage (though make that job a little longer).

comment.body:
Having thought a bit how to implement this (a script doing all alternatives in one build task, probably) I wonder whether this really gains us very much: CCI resource consumption, possibly; time-to-finish, probably not: Here's the thinking:

Presently we have three CCI jobs doing this (albeit sparse) "matrix". They do run in parallel in 13 mins: 
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/108313509-bc2e3c80-71b8-11eb-8cdb-ad3fddabc5ac.png)

To prove jobs in our CCI workflow setup already do run in parallel, here's how the ARM jobs are presently executing:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/108313840-3bbc0b80-71b9-11eb-800b-80c62f21e3cf.png)

On this basis, what if we move this all into one job? Isn't it so that this job will run (nearly - we save docker setup and clone) 3 times longer if it's just doing the same combinations (and considerably longer if we'd test the full matrix)? It needs to build all the same objects from source with the same fixed set of CPUs (within one CCI job) that we already use at maximum availability building with `ninja`.

When looking at [using CCI job parallelism](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/parallelism-faster-jobs/) (instead of that delivered by [workflows](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/workflows/#fan-outfan-in-workflow-example) as already used in our CCI config) and the option to at least run the tests of the different builds in parallel (after having built all objects in different `build` directories of _one_ job), another problem appears: Our `pytest` harness only permits testing a single `build` folder; one presently cannot specify running tests on executables in different folders, say `build_clang_noopenssl` and `build_gcc_openssl`) as per (for example) https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/952c628051f2b88aee02952abc46be0ac8f09ab7/tests/helpers.py#L68 . But even if we fix that, would we speed up stuff considerably given `pytest` already uses all core available to a single job's executor?

Asking for feedback especially from @xvzcf and @jschanck : Am I completely misunderstanding the proposal here? Or misunderstanding what CCI offers?

issue.title: Enabling all signature algorithms by default.
issue.body:
In [ssl/ssl_local.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L207), there are `#define`s that assign one-hot encodings to each signature algorithm. These encodings are used in [ssl/ssl_cert_table.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_cert_table.h#L26), and are assigned to a uint32_t variable called `amask` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/ssl/ssl_local.h#L1924).

Since the encodings are one-hot, at most 32 different signature algorithms can be encoded, and since 8 bits are already used up by OpenSSL by default, at most 24 different OQS signature algorithms can be encoded and assigned to `amask` at any given instant. 

This (possibly?) prevents us from enabling all signature algorithms by default, and the question is how we should deal with this.

comment.body:
TLDR: After checking the code I don't see a problem going beyond the possible `amask` bitcount (32) with OQS algorithms, i.e., activate all OQS-sigs. Minor caveat on clients not sending sigalgs: See below: Ideas how to trigger that welcome.

Full rationale:

Source code analysis (code review plus walk-through by debugger) of all places where `amask` is utilized (discarding/assuming as irrelevant its uses in `test` and its own declaration in `ssl_local.h`):

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/ssl_ciph.c#L2161
-> Sole use in auth disablement check: not applicable to OQS-OpenSSL as `disabled_auth_mask` is only ever set to legacy auth algorithms

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/statem/statem_clnt.c#L1959-L1960

--> use guarded for !TLS1_3: not applicable to OQS-OpenSSL (running only TLS1.3)

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/statem/statem_clnt.c#L3606

--> ECDSA only: not applicable to OQS-OpenSSL

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/statem/statem_clnt.c#L3597-L3598

--> No cipher alg is associated with an OQS auth alg; thus, this case cannot trigger (in testing for example cipher is always `TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384` ensuring this code path is not reached at all) -> also no issue

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/t1_lib.c#L1325

--> _seems_ OK, but cannot validate 100% as I do not know how to enforce the client to NOT send a list of supported sig types.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/t1_lib.c#L2231

--> Again, only operates on legacy algs in `disabled_mask`: Not applicable to OQS-OpenSSL

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/t1_lib.c#L3166

--> This code/function `tls12_get_cert_sigalg_idx` would only trigger on TLS < 1.3 as per this:

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/ssl/t1_lib.c#L3333

--> Again, not applicable to OQS-OpenSSL

issue.title: Combine tasks from some CI workflows to speed up builds
issue.body: Could have a single build that does shared, noshared, openssl, noopenssl, clang, gcc, rather than separate builds.  Would reduce overall CI usage (though make that job a little longer).

comment.body:
We have 3 ubuntu-focal jobs and the 2 alpine jobs that ask to be run in docker containers. CircleCI gives us 4 docker containers at once, so two jobs *will* get stacked. We just don't currently control which two.

Each of the alpine jobs takes ~ 9 minutes. Each of the ubuntu-focal jobs takes ~ 13  minutes. If you stack two alpine jobs, you have a depth of 18 minutes. On the other hand, if you stack two ubuntu-focal jobs, you have a depth of 26 minutes.

The situation was worse before we disabled centos and debian; it might not be worth changing unless we want to run more jobs.

issue.title: Use valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching on 'audit' branches

comment.body:
This is failing with a new type of timeout.

Options:
* Move this out of CI.
* Split into kem and sig jobs that run in separate containers.
* Skip some of the heavy schemes.

I'm happy to wait until after 0.5.0.

issue.title: Support OpenSSL on Windows
issue.body:
Attempts to add support for OpenSSL on Windows. We probably should add this to the CI matrix as well.

See also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/issues/17

comment.body:
> Why was BIKE even disabled on Win32 if that's just because of OpenSSL, because it works fine without OpenSSL on Linux and Mac...

Yeah, I went back to my original CMake commit to jog my memory, and it turns out I misspoke in the meeting. I disabled BIKE on Windows because it was not listed as being supported [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb458165698c5850dcf08d7268a2b6c90e47e378/VisualStudio/winconfig.h#L4), not because of OpenSSL; and from quickly skimming through the PR's most recent AppVeyor logs, it seems a bit more work might be required to get BIKE working on Windows.

issue.title: Combine tasks from some CI workflows to speed up builds
issue.body: Could have a single build that does shared, noshared, openssl, noopenssl, clang, gcc, rather than separate builds.  Would reduce overall CI usage (though make that job a little longer).

comment.body: OK -- if we target running the 4 parallel jobs we have, what about moving ubuntu-focal-noopenssl to the `require_testapproval` test-batch? a) It most likely won't tell us "early news" (that alpine-noopenssl wouldn't already tell us) and b) is running slower than the alpine run but faster than the arm ones, thus slowing no-one down. That way we'd have the same 4 jobs running in each "batch" (unless we want to run more jobs).

I suggest merging to main. We're not ready to do the full set of tests in CI.

I did run test_constant_time locally and it passed with the following patch to the suppression file.

```patch
diff --git a/tests/constant_time/kem/passes/sike-compressed b/tests/constant_time/kem/passes/sike-compressed
index 20303375..c4d96a67 100644
--- a/tests/constant_time/kem/passes/sike-compressed
+++ b/tests/constant_time/kem/passes/sike-compressed
@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@
    Memcheck:Cond
    ...
    fun:fp2inv*_mont_bingcd
-   src:sidh_compressed.c:590 # fun:FullIsogeny_A_dual
+   src:sidh_compressed.c:124 # fun:FullIsogeny_A_dual
 }
 
 {
@@ -49,5 +49,5 @@
    Memcheck:Cond
    ...
    fun:fp2inv*_mont_bingcd
-   src:sidh_compressed.c:993 # fun:FullIsogeny_B_dual
+   src:sidh_compressed.c:398 # fun:FullIsogeny_B_dual
 }
```

issue.title: Enable Build for other Platforms like ARM (Android)
issue.body:
First of all thanks for your good work :)  
I am trying to get the lib working for android.  Regarding https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/594 i am able to get a working .so file for android and the passed abi.  
But i am struggeling to get it working with this repository and jni.  
When i just compile the library for armv8a and then using this repo to get the jni wrapper it fails as the target system (x86) differs at compile time.     

<details>    
<summary>Excerpt of the error message</summary>   

```
[INFO] /bin/sh -c cd '/home/hatzen/liboqs-java' && 'gcc' '-shared' '-L/home/hatzen/liboqs/build/lib' '-o/home/hatzen/liboqs-java/target/liboqs-java.jar' 'target/objs/handle.o' 'target/objs/KEMs.o' 'target/objs/KeyEncapsulation.o' 'target/objs/Rand.o' 'target/objs/Signature.o' 'target/objs/Sigs.o' '-o' '/home/hatzen/liboqs-java/src/main/resources/liboqs-jni.so' '-loqs'
/usr/bin/ld: skipping incompatible /home/hatzen/liboqs/build/lib/liboqs.so when searching for -loqs
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -loqs
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
```
</details>  
  
So i tried to copy the necessary files and build jni and liboqs at a single time with the given cmake files.  
I copied all c sources and tried to add them to the cmakefile. Buti get errors when running the java test.    
  
<details>
<summary>Excerpts of changed files</summary>  
  
src/CMakeList.txt
```cmake  
...
include_directories(jni)
link_directories(jni oqs)

add_library(jni SHARED
jni/handle.c
jni/KEMs.c
jni/KeyEncapsulation.c
jni/Rand.c
jni/Signature.c
jni/Sigs.c)

set_target_properties(
    jni
    PROPERTIES
    COMPILE_FLAGS "-w"
    #COMPILE_WARNING_DISABLED high
)
target_link_libraries(jni oqs)

set_target_properties(jni PROPERTIES PUBLIC_HEADER "jni/handle.h;jni/KEMs.h;jni/KeyEncapsulation.h;jni/Rand.h;jni/Signature.h;jni/Sigs.h")

INSTALL(TARGETS jni
        LIBRARY DESTINATION lib
        PUBLIC_HEADER DESTINATION lib
)
...
```   
And i have overriden the Common Class of this Repo: 

```java
public class Common {
    ...
    public static void loadNativeLibrary() {
        // overrides all changes from this repo method.
        System.loadLibrary("oqs");
        System.loadLibrary("jni");
   }
   ...
}
```
I did override all packages and paths like:  
```
Java_org_openquantumsafe => Java_de_hartz_software_parannoying_helper_security_liboqs_java
org/openquantumsafe => de/hartz/software/parannoying/helper/security/liboqs/java
```

The crash occours probably on the equivalent of:  
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/109534741ace8442129b20dce9cfce62aa54048a/src/test/java/org/openquantumsafe/KEMTest.java#L37  
which is calling JNI  
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/109534741ace8442129b20dce9cfce62aa54048a/src/main/c/KeyEncapsulation.c#L41  

```
2021-01-02 20:21:08.357 7642-7697/de.hartz.software.parannoying E/zygote64: JNI ERROR (app bug): accessed stale Local 0x76e6ea9241  (index 1852746020 in a table of size 2)
2021-01-02 20:21:08.388 7642-7697/de.hartz.software.parannoying A/zygote64: java_vm_ext.cc:534] JNI DETECTED ERROR IN APPLICATION: use of deleted local reference 0x76e6ea9241
2021-01-02 20:21:08.389 7642-7697/de.hartz.software.parannoying A/zygote64: java_vm_ext.cc:534]     from de.hartz.software.parannoying.helper.security.liboqs.java.KeyEncapsulation$KeyEncapsulationDetails de.hartz.software.parannoying.helper.security.liboqs.java.KeyEncapsulation.get_KEM_details()
2021-01-02 20:21:08.389 7642-7697/de.hartz.software.parannoying A/zygote64: java_vm_ext.cc:534] "Instr: androidx.test.runner.AndroidJUnitRunner" prio=5 tid=22 Runnable
```
  
</details>
  
I am not very familiar with writing c and never had contact with JNI before.   
So i am not sure whether it could be simple to solve. So my question is will you consider to make this repo be able to build for different abis at a time?

comment.body:
I am still trying to get it work not successfully yet.  
I ran in issues with excecuting the java-liboqs project with `mvn package` when passing the lib as an argument. It gets packaged into the jar and extracted on runtime successfully but it is not recognized/ found when running the tests for some reason (https://github.com/Hatzen/LibOQSTestApp/issues/7)  
Running the circle ci steps manully with a predefined lib works like the badge is telling.  
Can anyone maybe confirm this problem for this repo?  
Does following https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java#building-the-java-oqs-wrapper without using a system wide available .so file work for anyone?

comment.body: Hi @Hatzen, sorry for the late reply. I don't have much experience with ARM and Android, but if it's a C-related problem, `liboqs-java` compiles the native (C) files in order to interact with `liboqs` [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/master/pom.xml#L135). Maybe the linking issue is there?
